RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:
Before working this US - make sure all Back Promotions from DevMerge have completed successfully.


I. Make Department Code an External Id field


  1. In your Dev2 Sandbox, go to the Department Object and find the Department Code field
  2. Edit the Department Code field, and check the box for External Id

II. Clean up the All Departments List View


  1. In your Dev2 Sandbox, update the "All" List View for Department to include
    1. Department Code
    2. Last Modified By

III. Clean up Department Object Layout


  1. In your Dev2 Sandbox, go to the Department Object and find the Department Layout.
  2. Edit the Department Layout so that it looks like this screenshot in Git when Previewed As System Administrator.
  3. Make sure to set the Sort of the Travel Approvals Related List to be by Travel Approval # Ascending


Should have only 3 Components in your Commit.


Promote/Deploy to DevMerge and Back Promote to the "sibling" Dev Sandbox

RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:
Before working this US - make sure all Back Promotions from DevMerge have completed successfully.


In your Dev1 Sandbox:


I. Add External Id Field to Travel Approval Object and fix Case Sensitivity for Destination State Field


  1. Create an External Id Field on the Travel Approval object:
    1. Label = External Id
    2. Field Name = External_Id
    3. Length = 18
    4. Required = True
    5. Unique = True
      1. Radial should be Case Sensitive
    6. External Id = True
  2. Create a new Validation Rule on the Travel Approval object:
    1. Rule Name = Destination_State_must_be_uppercase
    2. Active = True
    3. Error Condition Formula = Destination_State__c <> UPPER( Destination_State__c )
    4. Error Message = Destination State must be entered in UPPERCASE
    5. Error Location = Destination State

II. Clean up the All Travel Approvals List View


  1. In your Dev1 Sandbox, update the "All" List View for Travel Approvals to include External Id, Purpose of Trip, Status, Trip Start Date, Trip End Date, Destination State, Out-of-State, Department

III. Clean up Travel Approval Object Layout, Add Expense Items Related List and add Files Related List


  1. In your Dev1 Sandbox, go to the Travel Approval Object and find the Travel Approval Layout.
  2. Edit the Travel Approval Layout so that it looks like this screenshot in Git when Previewed As System Administrator.
  3. On the Expense Items Related List, make sure to set the Sort by Expense Item Number Ascending


Should have 5 Components in your Commit.


Promote/Deploy to DevMerge and Back Promote to the "sibling" Dev Sandbox.

RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:

    1. Make the Expense Type Field required in the Page Layout ONLY

Should have 3 Components in your Commit


Promote/Deploy to DevMerge and Back Promote to "sibling" Dev Sandbox

RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__User_Story_Title__c: Manual Task Only - Import Test Data to Test what you have built (see details below)
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:
Before working this US - make sure all Forward Promotions to DevMerge and all Back Promotions from DevMerge have completed successfully.


For this User Story, we will move it separate from all other User Stories.


First in DevMerge, you will manually import the 3 Data files from our Bootcamp Examples Git Repository to illustrate the free/manual option to get Test Data into an Environment in your Pipeline:


1. Departments (for DevMerge)

2. Travel Approvals (for DevMerge)

3. Expense Items (for DevMerge)


Once you have manually imported this data into DevMerge, you should Deploy all Sprint 1 User Stories with Sequence 1-7 from DevMerge to QA, but do NOT move Story Sequence 8 yet.

_______________


Next, after all other Sprint 1 and Sprint 2 User Stories have been completed and deployed to QA, we will move the Test Data on Sequence 8 into QA using Deployment Tasks of Type = Data (SOQL Queries) to illustrate the free/automated option to get Test Data into an Environment in your Pipeline.

_______________


Finally, after all other Sprint 1 and Sprint 2 User Stories have been deployed to UAT, we will leverage Copado Data Deploy (Data Templates) to illustrate the paid/automated option to get Test Data into an Environment in your Pipeline.


This User Story's End of Life will occur once the Test Data has been deployed into UAT.

RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:
Before you begin this US, make sure all Sprint 1 User Stories with Sequence 1-7 have been Deployed from DevMerge to QA and you have performed the free/automated Test Data Deployment with Sequence 8.


In your Dev2 Sandbox:


I. Update Travel Approval object's Search Layout and create a new List View for "Open Out of State Travel Requests"


  1. First, update the Search Layout for the Travel Approvals object.
    1. Click Search Layouts
    2. Click the down arrow for the Default Layout and select Edit from the dropdown.
    3. Use the Add arrow to move these fields into the Selected Fields column, in order.
      1. Purpose of Trip
      2. Department
      3. Status
      4. Destination State
      5. Trip Start Date
      6. Trip End Date
    4. Save
  2. Create the new List view for "Open Out of State Travel Requests" as prescribed here Create and Customize a List View


II. Enable Chatter on the Travel Approval Object


  1. In your Dev2 Sandbox, Enable Chatter for Travel Approvals


III. Customize the Travel Approval Object Layout for new Business Requirements


These Requirements for a new Travel Approval object's Lightning Page with Dynamic Forms enabled came in as an urgent addition to our Sprint. Rather than building the Lightning Page from scratch, or leveraging an Unmanaged Package to install, which carries a lot of Metadata Dependencies, we are going to deploy our new Travel Approval object's Lightning Page XML from Git into our Dev2 Sandbox, Activate the Lightning Page and then make our User Story Commits.


First, let's get the XML File for our new Travel Approval object's Lightning Page into our CopaBoot-Pipeline Repository and its dev2 Branch


  1. Go to Copado-Bootcamp/BootcampExamples/Travel_Approvals.flexipage
    1. Click Raw button
    2. Highlight all lines of this File from <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> down to </FlexiPage> and copy the contents to your clipboard
  2. Still in Git, change Repositories so that you are on your CopaBoot-Pipeline Repository on the dev2 Branch
  3. Within the dev2 Branch, open the flexipages folder
  4. Next, click Add File --> Create New File
    1. Now, name your file Travel_Approvals.flexipage and paste the contents you copied from Step #1b above into the File's body
      1. Scroll to the bottom of the File, keep the default radial selection for Commit directly to the dev2 branch and click Commit new file

Second, let's deploy the XML for our new Lightning Page from Git into our Dev2 Sandbox (p.s. this is a strategy we use with Customers when they accidentally refresh a Sandbox with Committed Work-in-Progress)


  1. Here in Copado, go to your Git Repository record for CopaBoot-Pipeline
  2. Click the Retrieve Commits button and in the pop-up window type dev2, then click Submit
    1. You may need to reload the Salesforce page in your Browser to see the retrieved Commits
  3. Next, click the Create Deployment button and fill out the fields at the top of the form - keep the default values for all fields, except the two below, and remember that case-sensitivity matters for the Branch:
    1. Deployment Name = Lightning Page for US Sequence 16
      1. Branch = dev2
  4. On this same screen, under the section Select Initial Commit
    1. Click on the COMMIT ID link for the Commit Message Create Travel_Approvals.flexipage
  5. On the next screen, under the section Select End Commit
    1. Click on the exact same COMMIT ID link for the Commit Message Create Travel_Approvals.flexipage
    2. On the final screen, click the Create Deployment button
  6. Now, go to the Deployments tab of Copado
  7. Locate and click on your Deployment named Lightning Page for US Sequence 16
    1. Add the To Credential for the Deployment as Dev2
      1. At the top-right panel of the Deployment, click Deploy, then Deploy All
    2. Confirm that your Deployment has a Deployment Step with Type = Git Metadata

Once your Deployment successfully completes


  1. Open the Dev2 Sandbox and confirm that you now have a new Lightning Page on the Travel Approval object
  2. Activate your new Travel Approval object's Lightning Page as an App Default for our Travel App


Should have 4 Components in your Commit.


Promote & Deploy this US to DevMerge and then to QA; once those 2 forward Promotions have Completed Successfully, then make sure to Back Promote to the "sibling" Dev Sandbox.

RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__User_Story_Title__c: Create New Custom Profile: Bootcamp Standard User
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:
Before working this US - make sure all Back Promotions from DevMerge have completed successfully.


In Dev1 Sandbox, since we know this Profile should have Minimum Access, other than our Travel App components, we will begin by Cloning the standard Minimum Access - Salesforce Profile.


  1. The new custom Profile Name should be Bootcamp Standard User
  2. The new custom Profile should grant Visibility of the Travel App custom App only (as the default app)
  3. The new custom Profile should grant Create/Read Permissions on all Objects in our Travel App and Edit Permission on their Fields
  4. The new custom Profile should grant Visibility of all Tabs included in the Travel App
  5. The new custom Profile should have the System Permissions "Lightning Experience User" and "Run Reports"
  6. The new custom Profile should grant NO other Permissions


Critical Concept Review


  1. Since you are wholly creating a net-new Profile, which Git Operation should you use?
    1. Is there more than one correct answer?


There should be 1 Component in your Commit


Promote & Deploy this US to DevMerge and then to QA; once those 2 forward Promotions have Completed Successfully, then make sure to Back Promote to the "sibling" Dev Sandbox.



Post-Deployment Clean-up


  1. Since we have YAML in place to suppress userPermissions, we will need to do some quick post-Deployment Manual cleanup:
    1. Clear all editable System Permissions in Target Environment except for Lightning Experience User and Run Reports
    2. Clear all editable App Permissions in Target Environment
  2. Additionally, some Standard Tabs are not passed in the API and simply default to "Default On" or "Default Off"
    1. clean them up in Target Environment so that you only have the Tabs for your Travel App as "Default On" and all other Tabs are Hidden
    2. Here is the Salesforce Help Article that explains the behavior, though, the article is written for Change Sets, but what Salesforce Partner Support explained is that it also applies to any API Deployment (therefore the same behavior occurs with Change Sets, the Ant Migration Tool, Workbench and any other Copado competitor's solution).

RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__User_Story_Title__c: Create New Permission Set: Manage Travel App Objects' Records
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:
Before working this US - make sure all Back Promotions from DevMerge have completed successfully.


In Dev2, create a new Permission Set Manage Travel App Objects' Records


  1. The new Permission Set Name should be Manage Travel App Objects' Records
  2. The new Permission Set should grant Full Permission to all Objects in our Travel App and Edit Permission on their Fields
  3. The new Permission Set Description should be:
    1. Assign to Users on the Bootcamp Standard Profile to extend Permissions on the Travel App Objects from Create/Read to Full Permission


Critical Concept Review


  1. Since you are wholly creating a net-new Permission Set, which Git Operation should you use?
    1. Is there more than one correct answer?


There should be 1 Component in your Commit


Promote & Deploy this US to DevMerge and then to QA; once those 2 forward Promotions have Completed Successfully, then make sure to Back Promote to the "sibling" Dev Sandbox.

RecordType.Name: User Story
copado__User_Story_Title__c: Delete Social Security Number and Mother's Maiden Name Fields from Contact Object
copado__Functional_Specifications__c:
From Hotfix, we need to delete two fields from the Contact object that our Auditors have flagged as critical PII and PCI violations:

> Social Security Number

> Mother's Maiden Name


This Story requires a Destructive Change in all Environments in the Pipeline.


Should have 2 components in your Commit.


Promote/Deploy to Production and, once the Deployment Completes Successfully, immediately Back Promote to UAT, QA, DevMerge and all Dev Sandboxes


Finally, manually delete these 2 fields in the Hotfix Sandbox and update the two End of Life checkboxes on this User Story only.
